content.description: A tricky start leads to easier climbing through the middle with a couple rests. Upper overhang is the crux with powerful compression on small and/or slopey holds.
content.protection: Bolts to a carabiner / open-cold shut anchor.
content.location: Just to the right of where the approach trail meets the wall. Route starts directly in front of a tree growing a foot from the base.

content.description: Climb up a gently overhanging wall on large and mostly straight-forward jugs. Turn the bulge and milk an ok rest with good feet while contemplating the boulder problem that guards the chains. Desperately search for solid holds until you can move high enough to clip the anchors. Pumpy!
content.protection: 4 bolts to mussy hooks.Â Shares anchor with Bang For Buck.
content.location: Far right end of the wall, just before it changes to slab. Left route of the two 4 bolt routes that share anchors.

content.description: Head up through disconnected cracks and sidepulls, doing a few big moves before a traverse left. Get a rest on top of the pillar, then head up through the shallow dihedral. A fun route, but suffers from low quality rock in places.
content.location: First bolted line just left of the fence.

content.description: Decent climbing up over a bulge and onto a very exposed feeling face above.
content.location: Start where a large tree is right up against the base of the wall. Second route right of the fence.

content.description: Left angling crack that leads to short roof then up onto the face.
content.location: Farthest left route before crossing the fence.

content.description: A silghtly dirty start up the slab on positive holds leads to a puzzling, thin crux pulling over a bulge. Get a decent rest, then fire off a dynamic move to a jug. Another thin, cruxy section guards the juggy finish.
content.location: Route just to left of Barfly.

climbs.name: Love is a Dog from Hell

content.description: This route features sharp rock, with some tricky hold-finding. Start is a mantle up onto a large block, from which you can clip a high second bolt. It progresses into an open book with crimps, leading to the crux move of pulling up and out of the open book section.
content.location: This is the 5th boltline from the left, beginning on a large, prominent shelf/block.

content.description: Slightly contrived; definitely thin.  Starts on a ramp and progresses to a thin face that looks like all the other thin faces in the area.
content.location: Starts under the large arc in the face (see photo).

content.description: Up a ramp with a tree at the top, into a crack. Steep technical climbing with some sloper holds above the crack. Watch out for some loose holds down low.
content.location: Look for a tree growing out of a crack above a 10' ramp.

content.description: This is a real gem.  Steep start leads to great right-hand side pulls with some pumpy sloping holds.  Sustained climbing to a lowering station.
content.location: In the steep part of the right-most section of the wall.  There is a rock stool at the base of this climb stacked up against a tree to form a nice belay chair.

content.description: Pull through the lower overhang on jugs, then puzzle through the less steep but more sequential face above. The last moves to the anchor require some thought and creativity.
content.protection: 4 bolts to mussy hooks. Shares an anchor with the route to the left (name currently unknown).
content.location: Far right end of the wall, just before it turns to slab.
